comments.body: would this be appreciably simpler if we handled ohlc separately?

I though about this, and actually if you look back at the commits there were points in time where I did this.

Ultimately I figured for now to just keep this as generic as possible and not special case things. That does add:
  
  1. An inner loop in this method AND
  2. Complexity for `_wrap_series_output` and `_wrap_aggregated_output`, as they now *might* need to build a DataFrame instead of a Series in (I assume) < 1% of cases

The upside of punting this for now is that there are other functions that aren't entirely generic. `ohlc` converts a Series into a DataFrame, but similarly `size`, `ngroup` and `cumcount` convert a DataFrame into a Series (see the test where these have to be skipped). It might make the most sense to prevent these from going through the `generic` module entirely, but not sure yet what the best approach is

Agree with @WillAyd, my preference is to just have the `f` were it's needed. Even in strings splitted in different lines.

As described in [pep-498-concatenating-strings](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0498/#concatenating-strings), regular strings are concatenated at compile time, and f-strings are concatenated at run time.

I think what we should not concatenate regular strings with f-strings because this could lead to unexpected results.

comments.body: i don't believe you actually need to do this which defeats the purpose of non-unique indexing

I think maybe we are thinking of different things? 
Here because we have `mutated == False` (more on that later), we want to restore the original order by index.
The problem is, when index is duplicated, you can't do `reindex` but resort to `Index.get_indexer_non_unique`, which produces duplicated results, see below.
```python
>>> import pandas as pd
>>> pd.__version__
'0.26.0.dev0+1724.gc5b793a2d'

>>> index = pd.Index([2, 1, 2])
>>> ser = pd.Series([0, 1, 2], index=index)
>>> ser
2    0
1    1
2    2
dtype: int64

>>> indexer, _ = index.get_indexer_non_unique([1, 2, 2])
>>> indexer
array([1, 0, 2, 0, 2], dtype=int64)

>>> ser.take(indexer)  # This doesn't give us the reordered result
1    1
2    0
2    2
2    0
2    2
dtype: int64

>>> from pandas.core import algorithms
>>> indexer = algorithms.unique1d(indexer)
>>> ser.take(indexer)  # This does give us what we want
1    1
2    0
2    2
dtype: int64

>>> ser.reindex([1, 2, 2])  # This results in ValueError
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ...
ValueError: cannot reindex from a duplicate axis
```

Perhaps are you thinking of the refactoring mentioned in #14927?
If we can actually deprecate the behavior of trying to guess if an object is mutated and just return a multi-indexed `DataFrame` like `groupby.transform` does, then it is true we don't need to deduplicate here. What I wrote here is more like a smaller scale fix/patch.

Am I understanding this correctly? Let me know.

            else:

Can you elaborate? I'm guessing you're thinking of passing how="var" to _cython_agg_general. But I don't see what that gets us, as it duplicates the code in var.

Any chance you can comment back on this? I think this introduces code duplication as is

@WillAyd Apologies, and I'll follow up on this PR if there is indeed some code duplication, but I don't think there is. What we're doing here is applying a composition of two functions, g composed with h, where h is cythonized. As far as I can tell, there is no way to pass this composition in and keep it cythonized. Also, there is no place to apply a post-processing function to a cythonized aggregation. If this is wrong, then the duplication should definitely be removed.
Yea we also have a function called `_get_cythonized_result` which accepts a callable as an argument to `post_processing`

Indeed I wasn't aware of this. Took a look into it, and what I'm finding is there are (at least) two different signatures for cython functions. The first is those used by _get_cythonized_result:

    result, labels, [vals], [mask], [ngroups]

and the second is that used in _aggregate (ignoring group_nth):

    result, counts, values, comp_ids, min_count

Here, comp_ids is the same as labels. Since var is used in _aggregate currently, the signature can't be changed to match what is expected in _get_cythonized_result. I hacked away at _get_cythonized_result and got it to work, but it seems to me that the two signature types should be sorted out first, otherwise the logic required for _get_cythonized_result is undesirable. This shouldn't be too much work because _get_cythonized_result is only used in a few places currently. If that sounds right, I'd like to raise an issue for this (I searched but couldn't find one).

Yea I doubt there is an issue for it already as its really a matter of internal refactor. Things are a bit messy in the groupby code...so sure any clean up opportunities you see we would certainly welcome PRs for. Thanks for looking

comments.body: is there a reason you are using .values here?

Without values, iLocIndexer._setitem_with_indexer takes a broken path when the index labels are not unique. It goes from using positional indexes to labels because of the BlockManager, which causes errors when the labels are not unique. This causes tests in test_groupby to fail. By using values, we are able to get around it.

comments.body:
I think it might be better to change DataFrame.sampe to call a routine algos.sample (IOW move the routine there, ex- the validation things, which are done in DataFrame.sample (and here)). you may need a helper routine as well for this. 

The reason for this is to avoid constantly doing all of the validation things *per-group*

That is a good point, I hadn't thought about repeating all the validation steps. Originally I was doing the input checks once and then just sampling the index by group, is this also a viable option? https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/34069/commits/b91b767c39dabaf6114cac2b5df4ed887f0c6d60

Edit: Sampling the underlying object index is wrong so that part would have to be changed.

It should be a Generator, not a BitGenerator. BitGenerator is the lower-level interface that only exposes the raw pseudo random numbers.  Also, are int or array-like seed values used with a RandomState or with a new BitGenerator?  Ideally one would limit the use of RandomState to end-user- provided RS and would use `np.random.default_rng([int, array_like])` if available.
Also, might be clearer to call the just `state` since `random_state` gives the impression that it is linked to a `RandomState`.

> It should be a Generator, not a BitGenerator.

You could be right, I was honestly lifting this docstring for the most part from the one for NDFrame.sample. If this is not correct we'd need to update it there as well as the random_state function in /core/common.py.

> Also, might be clearer to call the just state since random_state gives the impression that it is linked to a RandomState.

I feel we'd want to share the same naming convention used by NDFrame.sample and sklearn.

Ahh, I misread it.  It does take a BitGenerator, which is sort of like a seed.  So it is correct. I understand the point of wanting compact.  I is unfortunate that `random_state` has become so ubiquitous since it makes moving to better practices or better rngs more difficult.

comments.body: Do groups have to have the same number of elements?  I don't seem to be able to understand how this would work in general.
It won't work in general, we'll get an error if n is larger than one of the group sizes and replace is False

If I understand your example, weights has the same size as the index of the underlying DF or Series where the groupby has been applied? So in principle it could be a column from the same DF, like
```
df.groupby("a").sample(1, weights=df.weights)
```
Maybe you should state that it must have at least 1 non-zero entry per group.
Passing a list appears to only work if the underlying DF or Series has a standard RangeIndex(0, nobs).
Thanks for pointing this out. Should be fixed and I updated the weights test to look at this type of case.
